snippet.title: Global warming progression cannot be denied
snippet.content: THERE is one undeniable fact associated with climate disruption. Doubters or deniers of climate disruption are universally politically conservative. This seems to be true mainly in Australia and the USA, however. In most other nations of the world, climate change, as a result of global warming, is understood and accepted bipartisanly. The simple explanation, here, is that conservative voters embrace small government, low taxes, private ownership and free enterprise. If one holds these values dear, it's hard to believe in global warming because the solution, at this late time, requires government action, carbon taxes and involvement. Private industry, as many separate entities, does not seem capable of responding to such an enormous challenge. There may be much more to this, though, as everywhere else in the world both conservative and progressive parties are working together to realise a carbon-neutral society. Mr Buick (Daily, July 28) got one thing correct in his remarkable anti-green rant. Global warming predictions are debunked monthly. It seems the IPCC, that UN body initiated by Margaret Thatcher to monitor climate disruption and predict some of its consequences, has underestimated almost all of the increases in temperature. Global warming is progressing much faster than predicted. Stopping the Adani coal mine would be a great way for Labor to start making sense.
